quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When we look at the skills required to do your job, by 2030, it will change by 70%. So whether or not you're looking to change your job, your job is changing. In order to stay competitive, you actually have to go back to some first principles, go back to the drawing board and reimagine what it means to be building.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete data point and call to action to rethink how you build as job requirements rapidly shift.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We call it the full stack builder model. The goal itself is to empower great builders to take their idea and to take it to market, regardless of their role and the stack and which team they're on. It's really fluid interaction between human and machine.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Introduces a new operating model for product development centered on end-to-end ownership enabled by human+AI collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Change management here is going to be a critical part, but it's not enough to give them the tools. You have to build the incentives programs, the motivation, the examples to how you do it. I see a lot of companies roll out their agents and just expecting companies to adopt. It doesn't work this way.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Practical guidance that adoption requires incentives and enablement—not just deploying AI tools.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They've scrapped their APM program and replaced it with an associate full stack builder program.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific organizational change example showing how LinkedIn is restructuring talent pipelines around AI-native building.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta helps companies of all sizes get compliant fast and stay that way with industry-leading AI, automation, and continuous monitoring.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach to compliance: automate and continuously monitor rather than treating compliance as a one-time project.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta also helps you complete security questionnaires up to five times faster so that you can win bigger deals sooner.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Connects operational efficiency (faster questionnaires) directly to revenue outcomes (closing bigger deals sooner).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to a recent IDC study, Vanta customers slashed over $500,000 a year and are three times more productive.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Provides concrete ROI data points practitioners can use to justify investment in compliance automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stop spending so much time telling people about your product vision, and instead show it to them.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Figma)
quotes.context: Actionable product communication advice: use prototypes to align stakeholders and validate with customers faster.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With just a few prompts, you can make any idea or design into a fully functional prototype or app that anyone can iterate on and validate with customers.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Figma)
quotes.context: A methodology shift toward rapid, prompt-driven prototyping to accelerate iteration and customer validation.

quotes.topic_title: Why traditional product building became too complex
quotes.text: technology has always been about empowerment. It's not about what it does for us. It's about what enables us to do.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A first-principles lens for evaluating AI and product work: focus on capability amplification rather than feature output.

quotes.topic_title: Why traditional product building became too complex
quotes.text: we're entering this phase where the time constant of change is far greater than the time constant of response. Basically means that change is happening faster than we're able to respond to it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why legacy product processes break down under accelerating market/tech shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Why traditional product building became too complex
quotes.text: When we look at the skills required to do your job, by 2030, which is literally four years from now, sounds a long time, but four years from now, it will change by 70%.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete data point that quantifies the magnitude and urgency of workforce and product adaptation.

quotes.topic_title: Why traditional product building became too complex
quotes.text: You never see success in the launch itself.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder to optimize teams and process for iteration loops, not just shipping milestones.

quotes.topic_title: Why traditional product building became too complex
quotes.text: now we have this real opportunity to collapse the stack backup, go back to craftsmanship, rethink the product development lifecycle, which is where the full stack builder model comes to life.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A clear strategic direction/framework: use AI to reduce process/org complexity and re-center on end-to-end builders.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn data on skill disruption and job churn
quotes.text: we've never seen such a dramatic part of your role today.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights that the current wave of change is qualitatively larger than normal skill evolution, implying practitioners should plan for major role redesign rather than incremental upskilling.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn data on skill disruption and job churn
quotes.text: So whether you are a marketer right now or a seller, a recruiter, an engineer. Engineering is where a lot of the investment is going in right now in terms of agents. Those jobs will change dramatically.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Points to where AI investment is concentrating (engineering/agents), signaling which functions may face the fastest workflow disruption.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn data on skill disruption and job churn
quotes.text: just thinking about in four years, what did it take to actually engineer really, really well would be dramatically different, or to build software, to build an artifact of some sort.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete time horizon (four years) that encourages teams to re-scope competency models and hiring plans sooner than typical multi-year cycles.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn data on skill disruption and job churn
quotes.text: Some job like nurses will see less impact, but some jobs will see 90%, 95% impact.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Provides a stark range of disruption, useful for prioritizing which roles to redesign first based on expected impact.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn data on skill disruption and job churn
quotes.text: 70% of today's fastest growing jobs were not even on the list of jobs a year ago.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable churn statistic that supports building adaptable career ladders and org structures rather than optimizing for static job titles.

quotes.topic_title: Full Stack Builder model: goals and builder traits
quotes.text: Yeah. So we call it the full stack builder model. And the goal, always start with the goal. The goal itself is to empower great builders to take their idea and to take it to market, regardless of their role and the stack and specifically which team they're on.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Defines a practitioner-friendly model and a clear goal statement teams can use to align org design and tooling around empowering builders.

quotes.topic_title: Full Stack Builder model: goals and builder traits
quotes.text: And it's not a sequence of steps. It's really a fluid interaction between human and machine. That's how the way I see it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Reframes product development from a linear process to a human+AI workflow loop, changing how teams should design their operating cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Full Stack Builder model: goals and builder traits
quotes.text: And then ultimately what I think is the most important trait for a builder is judgment. Some people call it test making, but it's making high quality decisions in what is complex ambiguous situations. Everything else, I'm working really hard to automate. Really, really hard.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: invest human time in judgment under ambiguity and aggressively automate the rest.

quotes.topic_title: Full Stack Builder model: goals and builder traits
quotes.text: And an analogy I have in mind is kind of Navy SEALs. You come to training, they're all kind of learning, they're cross-trained, across multiple areas. What they specialize in is the mission and they operate in small pods and they're very nimble and you can assemble them very quickly.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable org-design mental model for building cross-functional, mission-specialized pods that can be rapidly assembled and redeployed.

quotes.topic_title: Full Stack Builder model: goals and builder traits
quotes.text: Yeah. It's not that you have to break the model. I think the model is broken. It's just this pace of change is helping us realize it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Challenges the default assumption that traditional product orgs just need tweaks—arguing the environment is exposing a fundamentally broken model.

quotes.topic_title: Three pillars: platform, agents/tools, and culture
quotes.text: And there's really three components that we're working on. One is platform. The second one is the tools and the agents. And lastly is the culture.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A clear three-pillar adoption framework for how large companies should approach AI transformation beyond just buying tools.

quotes.topic_title: Three pillars: platform, agents/tools, and culture
quotes.text: But the platform for us as an example is rearchitecting all of our core platforms so AI can reason over it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights that real AI leverage often requires foundational platform re-architecture so models can effectively operate on internal systems.

quotes.topic_title: Three pillars: platform, agents/tools, and culture
quotes.text: So you can't just go and bring a third party tool and have it work on the LinkedIn stack. In fact, that's one of our biggest learnings. It never works. Never works.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that off-the-shelf AI tooling typically fails in complex enterprise environments without deep integration work.

quotes.topic_title: Three pillars: platform, agents/tools, and culture
quotes.text: So we need to bring all of that know how and context and information base into that agent. So we ended up building our own trust agent at LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete example of when building an internal agent is necessary because domain-specific context (like trust) is unique and non-transferable.

quotes.topic_title: Internal agents: trust, growth, research, and analytics
quotes.text: So when you build a spec, you build an idea, you walk through the trust agent and it'll basically tell you what are your vulnerabilities, what harm vectors potentially you're introducing or will be introduced as a result of that.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete methodology: run product specs through a dedicated trust agent to proactively surface vulnerabilities and harm vectors.

quotes.topic_title: Internal agents: trust, growth, research, and analytics
quotes.text: So we walked that spec from a couple of years ago through the trust agent. Not only was it able to find all the stuff we initiated at the beginning, but all the holes that we did not catch until later.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A specific example showing internal agents can uncover issues teams miss—even after launch—making the case for systematic pre-mortems via AI.

quotes.topic_title: Internal agents: trust, growth, research, and analytics
quotes.text: We've kind of funneled all of our unique loops, our funnels, our tests of the past, everything into this growth agent, and now you can basically rock your respect for it, your idea for it. And it would not just allow you to do it better. It would actually critique how good is your idea.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A reusable internal-growth framework: encode historical loops/funnels/experiments into an agent that critiques new ideas, not just executes them.

quotes.topic_title: Internal agents: trust, growth, research, and analytics
quotes.text: So research agent basically is trained on the personas of our members. You can think about a small business owner, a job seeker and so on. And it's using not just world knowledge, it's using all the research we've done in the past, all the support tickets coming in.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical approach to making AI useful internally: ground persona reasoning in proprietary research and support-ticket data, not generic LLM knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: Internal agents: trust, growth, research, and analytics
quotes.text: We have an analyst agent trained on all how you basically can query the entire LinkedIn graph, which is enormous. And instead of relying on your SQL queries or data science teams, you can use the analyst agent.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A workflow shift: use an analyst agent to self-serve insights from complex internal data systems without bottlenecking on SQL or data science teams.

quotes.topic_title: How agents are built and orchestrated
quotes.text: By far though, the most important part was basically our own customization of it. That's been where we saw the biggest gains.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Emphasizes that the biggest ROI comes from internal customization on top of enterprise LLM platforms, not just adopting them off-the-shelf.

quotes.topic_title: How agents are built and orchestrated
quotes.text: Even building the orchestrator across those because you want the agents to start following to each other, the trust agent should work with the growth agent and go do a back and forth versus doing what more sequentially.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Introduces an orchestration model where specialized agents collaborate iteratively rather than running in a linear pipeline.

quotes.topic_title: How agents are built and orchestrated
quotes.text: And interestingly enough, and this is another learning, different teams gravitate to different products.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights a practical adoption challenge: tool choice varies by team, so standardization and integration become part of the agent strategy.

quotes.topic_title: How agents are built and orchestrated
quotes.text: And ultimately, I don't want to have eight design agents in the company, so we have to converge into at least a few.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete operational principle: limit agent/tool sprawl by converging on a small set to reduce fragmentation and overhead.

quotes.topic_title: How agents are built and orchestrated
quotes.text: But now we're starting with that building blocks until we build the orchestrating layer across.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Describes a phased methodology: start with measurable specialist agents as building blocks, then add an orchestration layer later.

quotes.topic_title: Automation focus: idea-to-design vs code-to-launch
quotes.text: There is the idea to design part, and then let's call it the code to launch part.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Introduces a simple two-stage framework for where to apply AI in product development beyond just coding.

quotes.topic_title: Automation focus: idea-to-design vs code-to-launch
quotes.text: In fact, I think we're close to 50% of all those builds being done by the maintenance agent and a QA agent.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete adoption metric showing meaningful automation impact in the code-to-launch phase.

quotes.topic_title: Automation focus: idea-to-design vs code-to-launch
quotes.text: It's not great to just give it access to your drive and say, "Reason all over this knowledge base." It actually does a very poor job understanding importance of the past and putting weights on stuff.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that broad “connect everything” approaches can degrade AI usefulness without curation.

quotes.topic_title: Automation focus: idea-to-design vs code-to-launch
quotes.text: The most important part was feeding at the right data, not all the data.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable principle for building effective AI systems: prioritize curated “golden” inputs over exhaustive access.

quotes.topic_title: Automation focus: idea-to-design vs code-to-launch
quotes.text: You have to put this initial work to get the gains after.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Practical guidance that teams should expect upfront investment (data cleanup, examples, process) before velocity/quality improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 76% of people believe that AI can benefit their role, but over 50% of people struggle to know when to use it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point highlighting that the main barrier to AI adoption is not belief in value, but knowing when to apply it.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enter Miro's innovation workspace, an intelligent platform that brings people and AI together in a shared space to get great work done.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical workflow model: embed AI into the same collaborative space where teams already work to reduce friction and increase usage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Teams especially can work with Miro AI to turn to unstructured data like sticky notes or screenshots into usable diagrams, product briefs, data tables, and prototypes in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, actionable use case for applying AI to convert messy inputs into structured product artifacts quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You don't have to be an AI master or to toggle yet another tool. The work you're already doing in Miro's Canvas is the prompt.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive adoption insight: teams can get value from AI without prompt expertise by treating existing work as the input.

quotes.topic_title: Pilot status, metrics, and early outcomes
quotes.text: So the way I think about the benefits is a function of experimentation volume multiplied by quality. How good are those experiments divided by the time it takes to actually pull them out, like idea to launch.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete metric framework for evaluating AI/productivity programs by combining throughput, quality, and cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: Pilot status, metrics, and early outcomes
quotes.text: So on saving times, we're seeing, whether it's PMs, designers, engineers, saving hours of work a week right now, whether it's the analyst agent we talked about or the prototyping really quickly or the product jamming experience has been a big part of that.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Specific early outcomes and examples of where time savings are showing up across roles.

quotes.topic_title: Pilot status, metrics, and early outcomes
quotes.text: On the quality side, we're seeing insights discussions just be much, much better.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights a quality improvement vector (better decision-making conversations), not just speed gains.

quotes.topic_title: Pilot status, metrics, and early outcomes
quotes.text: And by the way, quality and time, sometimes they help each other because it's high quality, you don't have to spend as much time on something.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive point that higher quality can reduce total time, challenging the usual quality-vs-speed tradeoff.

quotes.topic_title: Pilot status, metrics, and early outcomes
quotes.text: But we're seeing designers and PMs picking up bugs directly from Jira tickets, pushing them in, something we haven't seen before, and there's just an appetite for everybody to just join.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete behavioral change indicating broader empowerment and shifting ownership patterns enabled by the tools.

quotes.topic_title: How the pilot is run: pods and early adopters
quotes.text: So basically we are looking at specific areas that we're basically giving it to. The condition there is they give feedback. As a response for that, they make the tool better, so it's not just access. We want people who will use it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical rollout mechanism: gate early access on structured feedback to ensure real usage and rapid iteration.

quotes.topic_title: How the pilot is run: pods and early adopters
quotes.text: So that team actually, this was PMs building their own dashboards with those tools without waiting for design resources to come in.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Concrete example of AI/tools enabling role expansion and faster shipping by removing traditional dependency bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: How the pilot is run: pods and early adopters
quotes.text: And in many ways, what I tell this team is, "Don't wait for the official GA. Start doing it. Start leaning in."
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Counter to conventional “wait for GA” process—encourages early adoption to build capability and momentum ahead of formal rollout.

quotes.topic_title: How the pilot is run: pods and early adopters
quotes.text: We're seeing designers of that team starting to push PRs, which never happened before.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Memorable indicator of behavior change: tools can blur functional boundaries and create new cross-functional operating norms.

quotes.topic_title: How the pilot is run: pods and early adopters
quotes.text: We're going to teach them how to code, design and PM at LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A clear talent strategy shift toward “full-stack” product builders as a scalable way to operationalize the new model.

quotes.topic_title: Replacing APM with Associate Product Builder program
quotes.text: The product executive teams, basically we move from functional leaders, design, PM, BD, and so on to product areas leaders, and they basically rock across the stack and they also go for a 360 with all of those functions to see if they're really able to do a full stack building experience.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete org-design shift from functional leadership to full-stack product-area leadership, with 360 feedback as the validation mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Replacing APM with Associate Product Builder program
quotes.text: We're going to teach them how to code, design and PM at LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A specific, actionable model for developing junior product talent as multi-skill builders rather than single-track PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Replacing APM with Associate Product Builder program
quotes.text: And in many ways, we're going to use that training to think about how we roll it across the organization.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Positions the junior program as a pilot whose curriculum becomes a template for broader company-wide upskilling.

quotes.topic_title: Replacing APM with Associate Product Builder program
quotes.text: We're kind of using the lens of you have great technical skills, but you're not an engineer at a company yet, or you have great design taste, but you haven't designed at scale in company yet, and we're going to teach you how to do it at LinkedIn, but the training we're going to use a lot to extend across the company as well.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for bridging the gap between raw skill and operating effectively at company scale—and then reusing that training to uplift everyone.

quotes.topic_title: Adoption reality: top performers, incentives, and change management
quotes.text: In fact, our top talent are the ones who are using this the most at LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive adoption insight: the best performers often adopt AI first and drive the strongest early results.

quotes.topic_title: Adoption reality: top performers, incentives, and change management
quotes.text: This is why I had this phrase I say with the team that if we build all those tools, will they use it? And I know right now the answer is no. It's not enough to give them the tools to use it. You have to build the incentives programs, the motivation, the examples to how you do it. They need to see other people being successful as well.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical change-management model: tools are insufficient without incentives, motivation, and visible examples of success.

quotes.topic_title: Adoption reality: top performers, incentives, and change management
quotes.text: Some will adopt. That tends to be your cutting edge 5% of talent that just wants new tools and they have a bias for change. But the vast majority needs to work for change management in how they do it, and that requires being a lot more thoughtful about the cultural aspect of it, which is by far from me the biggest and most important thing to do.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete adoption heuristic (the “cutting edge 5%”) and a reminder that culture/change management is the main scaling bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Adoption reality: top performers, incentives, and change management
quotes.text: So everything from how you hire to calibration and evaluation.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Actionable lever: bake AI expectations into core people processes (hiring, performance calibration, evaluation) to drive behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Adoption reality: top performers, incentives, and change management
quotes.text: Literally one of our head of partnerships just went and did it himself. Didn't even delegate to his team. And their goal is to say like, "Hey, I can do it. You can do it as well."
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A vivid internal example of “pilot success” as a scaling tactic—leaders modeling hands-on usage to create contagious adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Embedding AI expectations into evaluation and reviews
quotes.text: Once I moved my team, my directs, we did 360 for them.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: He describes using 360 reviews as a concrete mechanism to shift expectations and reinforce desired behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Embedding AI expectations into evaluation and reviews
quotes.text: So their 360 was, if you came from PM, you had the designers on your team rate you.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A specific cross-functional evaluation design that encourages full-stack collaboration and accountability beyond one’s function.

quotes.topic_title: Embedding AI expectations into evaluation and reviews
quotes.text: But then we broadly took it across. So when we hire right now, we look for those.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: He explains scaling the same expectations from performance reviews into hiring criteria to reinforce consistency across the talent lifecycle.

quotes.topic_title: Embedding AI expectations into evaluation and reviews
quotes.text: And then this upcoming cycle, we do a bi-annual. That's going to be part of the performance evaluation piece and we announce it to everybody.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: He outlines an operational rollout plan—making it recurring and explicitly communicated—to drive adoption and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Embedding AI expectations into evaluation and reviews
quotes.text: It's always about, like, "I want to know how I'm being rated or evaluated."
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A behavioral insight: transparency about evaluation criteria can motivate engagement and performance.
